title: 115_hr1499
content: The Act may be cited as the "Remedies for Refusal of Repatriation Act" and includes definitions. The Act, titled "Remedies for Refusal of Repatriation Act," defines key terms such as "appropriate committees of Congress," "crime of violence," and "felony." The Act defines "felony" as a crime classified as a felony in the convicting jurisdiction or an offense under certain immigration laws with a term of imprisonment exceeding 1 year. SEC. 3. REMEDIES FOR SYSTEMATIC REFUSAL OF REPATRIATION. The Secretary of Homeland Security must establish procedures within 60 days to determine if a foreign country systematically refuses or delays repatriating their nationals who have been ordered removed from the US due to felony convictions, violent crimes, or posing a threat to national security. Countries refusing to repatriate such individuals will be listed for systematic refusal or delay. The Secretary of Homeland Security must establish procedures within 60 days to determine if a foreign country systematically refuses or delays repatriating their nationals who have been ordered removed from the US due to felony convictions, violent crimes, or posing a threat to national security. Countries refusing to repatriate such individuals will be listed for systematic refusal or delay. The country must secure documents to identify the nationality of the individual or have a government official interview the individual to determine their nationality if other factors indicate systematic refusal or delay in repatriation. The Secretary of Homeland Security must notify the Secretary of State if a country systematically refuses or delays repatriating their nationals who have been ordered removed from the US. They must meet with representatives of the foreign government to address the issue, and the US may stop issuing visas to nationals of that country. States may discontinue visa issuance to countries that systematically and unreasonably delay repatriating their nationals, as per section 243(d) of the Immigration and Nationality Act. The Secretary of Homeland Security may discontinue visa issuance to countries that delay repatriating their nationals. If deemed necessary, a report must be submitted to Congress explaining the decision. Countries failing to repatriate their nationals will be listed on the departments' websites, and an annual report identifying such countries will be submitted to Congress. The Secretary of Homeland Security and the Secretary of State identify countries meeting criteria, describe actions taken, notify countries failing to meet criteria and delaying repatriation, and take necessary actions.
